Award.AwardTitle: REU Site for 2-Year Undergraduates in Chemistry at Texas A&M University- Commerce
Award.AbstractNarration: This award by the Chemistry Division supports a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at Texas A&M University-Commerce for the summers of 2009-2011. The program director is Ben Jang who is assisted by co-PI Stephen Starnes. Ten students each year will be recruited from 2-year community colleges in the Northeast Texas area, with total enrollment of over 220,000 and more than 60,000 majors in chemistry, physics, pre-professional, and pre-engineering and non-science majors taking science courses. Ten selected student researchers, eight supported by NSF and two by Texas A&M U.-Commerce are required to go through basic training and project-based instrumentation training followed by working intensively with mentors on redesigned collaborative research projects. Experiences and momentum gained from the REU program in 2006-2008 will be used to expand the impact on student participants. A Special Topic course will be required for students to increase their level of preparation for productive research. At the end of the program, every student will participate in a poster session open to university community and their home colleges, to summarize their research accomplishments. The project is a novel way to reach community college students with a local setting for efficient follow-up. It is expected that the REU site will be a model to provide opportunities to 2-year college students in underserved regions of the nation for effective STEM recruitments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the 2009-2012 REUproject at TAMU-Commerce was to continue the previous successful REU project by providing interdisciplinary research opportunities for a diverse population of community college students in the Northeast Texas area who were unlikely to have a research opportunity before they commit to their pre-mature career paths. There were 23 community colleges in the Northeast area of Texas serving rural, urban and suburban undergraduate students with total enrollment of over 173,000 which include majors in chemistry, physics, pre-professional, and pre-engineering and non-science majors. Approximately 45,000 of these students currently enrolled in science courses and yet most did not persist to college graduation with a STEM degree. Ten student researchers were to be selected based not only on the GPA, but also on the recommendation of the instructors, the laboratory skills, and problem solving abilities with special emphasis given to the recruitment of underrepresented groups typically enrolled in the community colleges in thisregion.

The major goals of the project were:

Goal 1: Provide research opportunities in Chemistry at TAMU-Commerce for 8-10 students from community colleges in the Northeast Texas region. Goal 2: Encourage community college students to successfully transfer to a four year university to complete baccalaureate and graduate degrees leading to a STEM career. Goal 3: Sustain the effort built by the current REU to achieve a higher success rate in STEM by encouraging students to transfer to TAMU-Commerce with continued nurturing and mentoring in science departments via support from the S-STEMproject recently recommended for funding.

Overall, the 3-yr project recruited total 33 students including 28 students from 9 different community colleges in the Northeast Texas region and 5 students from TAMU-Commerce. Out of 28 community college students, who did not have prior research opportunities, 12 of them were female. There were 5 Hispanic and one African American among 28 students. One female student was a single mom and another female student required family housing for her husband to stay when he came to visit. 50% of the REU students (14 of the 28) from community colleges transferredto TAMU-Commerce after their REU experiences. 12 of 14 finished their BS degrees and 2 dropped out. These REU students produced eight publications in peer-reviewed journals, such as JACS, J. Catal., etc. and more than 40 presentations in conferences, such as ACS SWRMs, ACS DFW MiM, Texas A&M System Pathway Symposiums, etc., since 2010.

Intellectual Merit: Experiences and momentum gained from the initial REU program (2006-2008) had successfully expanded the impact on undergraduate researchers of the 2009-2012 project. All participants completed basic laboratory and project-based instrumentation training followed by intensive work with faculty mentors on newly designed collaborative research projects. Two field trips per year to world class companies and institutions were effective in helping students connect basic research in the labs to applied research in the industry. Workshops, including presentation and scientific writing skills and research ethics, were very beneficial to prepare students for their career at the next level. The research projects represented critical research areas and the knowledge gained had improved the fundamental understanding and accelerated the development of these fields as evidenced by the publications and presentations
